SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: What you command, that rests in me to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then I will do what your grace commands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to CLARENCE He plies her hard; and much rain
wears the marble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to GLOUCESTER As red as fire! nay, then
her wax must melt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to CLARENCE The match is made; she seals it
with a curtsy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense.
What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers;
That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: My mind will never grant what I perceive
Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower;
For by that loss I will not purchase them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me.
But, mighty lord, this merry inclination
Accords not with the sadness of my suit:
Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request;
No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to CLARENCE The widow likes him not, she
knits her brows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to GLOUCESTER He is the bluntest wooer in
Christendom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Her looks do argue her replete with modesty;
Her words do show her wit incomparable;
All her perfections challenge sovereignty:
One way or other, she is for a king;
And she shall be my love, or else my queen.--
Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord:
I am a subject fit to jest withal,
But far unfit to be a sovereign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee
I speak no more than what my soul intends;
And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: And that is more than I will yield unto:
I know I am too mean to be your queen,
And yet too good to be your concubine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY GREY
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: No more than when my daughters call thee mother.
Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children;
And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor,
Have other some: why, 'tis a happy thing
To be the father unto many sons.
Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to CLARENCE The ghostly father now hath done
his shrift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to GLOUCESTER When he was made a shriver,
'twas for shift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: You'll think it strange if I should marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: To whom, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Clarence, to myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both
Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nobleman
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken,
And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: See that he be convey'd unto the Tower:
And go we, brothers, to the man that took him,
To question of his apprehension.
Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Edward will use women honourably.
Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all,
That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring,
To cross me from the golden time I look for!
And yet, between my soul's desire and me--
The lustful Edward's title buried--
Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward,
And all the unlook'd for issue of their bodies,
To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:
A cold premeditation for my purpose!
Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty;
Like one that stands upon a promontory,
And spies a far-off shore where he would tread,
Wishing his foot were equal with his eye,
And chides the sea that sunders him from thence,
Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way:
So do I wish the crown, being so far off;
And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;
And so I say, I'll cut the causes off,
Flattering me with impossibilities.
My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much,
Unless my hand and strength could equal them.
Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard;
What other pleasure can the world afford?
I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap,
And deck my body in gay ornaments,
And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.
O miserable thought! and more unlikely
Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!
Why, love forswore me in my mother's womb:
And, for I should not deal in her soft laws,
She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe,
To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub;
To make an envious mountain on my back,
Where sits deformity to mock my body;
To shape my legs of an unequal size;
To disproportion me in every part,
Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp
That carries no impression like the dam.
And am I then a man to be beloved?
O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!
Then, since this earth affords no joy to me,
But to command, to cheque, to o'erbear such
As are of better person than myself,
I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown,
And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell,
Until my mis-shaped trunk that bears this head
Be round impaled with a glorious crown.
And yet I know not how to get the crown,
For many lives stand between me and home:
And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood,
That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns,
Seeking a way and straying from the way;
Not knowing how to find the open air,
But toiling desperately to find it out,--
Torment myself to catch the English crown:
And from that torment I will free myself,
Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,
And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart,
And wet my cheeks with artificial tears,
And frame my face to all occasions.
I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;
I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;
I'll play the orator as well as Nestor,
Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,
And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.
I can add colours to the chameleon,
Change shapes with Proteus for advantages,
And set the murderous Machiavel to school.
Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?
Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. France. KING LEWIS XI's palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING LEWIS XI, his sister BONA, his Admiral, called BOURBON, PRINCE EDWARD, QUEEN MARGARET, and OXFORD. KING LEWIS XI sits, and riseth up again

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret,
Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state
And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: No, mighty King of France: now Margaret
Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve
Where kings command. I was, I must confess,
Great Albion's queen in former golden days:
But now mischance hath trod my title down,
And with dishonour laid me on the ground;
Where I must take like seat unto my fortune,
And to my humble seat conform myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
And stops my tongue, while heart is drown'd in cares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Whate'er it be, be thou still like thyself,
And sit thee by our side:
Yield not thy neck
To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind
Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;
It shall be eased, if France can yield relief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.
Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis,
That Henry, sole possessor of my love,
Is of a king become a banish'd man,
And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn;
While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York
Usurps the regal title and the seat
Of England's true-anointed lawful king.
This is the cause that I, poor Margaret,
With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir,
Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid;
And if thou fail us, all our hope is done:
Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight,
And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm,
While we bethink a means to break it off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: The more I stay, the more I'll succor thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow.
And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise;
For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend,
I come, in kindness and unfeigned love,
First, to do greetings to thy royal person;
And then to crave a league of amity;
And lastly, to confirm that amity
With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant
That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister,
To England's king in lawful marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Aside If that go forward, Henry's hope is done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: To BONA And, gracious madam, in our king's behalf,
I am commanded, with your leave and favour,
Humbly to kiss your hand, and with my tongue
To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart;
Where fame, late entering at his heedful ears,
Hath placed thy beauty's image and thy virtue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak,
Before you answer Warwick. His demand
Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love,
But from deceit bred by necessity;
For how can tyrants safely govern home,
Unless abroad they purchase great alliance?
To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice,
That Henry liveth still: but were he dead,
Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son.
Look, therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage
Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;
For though usurpers sway the rule awhile,
Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Injurious Margaret!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: And why not queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Because thy father Henry did usurp;
And thou no more are prince than she is queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt,
Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain;
And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;
And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth,
Who by his prowess conquered all France:
From these our Henry lineally descends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse,
You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost
All that which Henry Fifth had gotten?
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
But for the rest, you tell a pedigree
Of threescore and two years; a silly time
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege,
Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years,
And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right,
Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?
For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Call him my king by whose injurious doom
My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere,
Was done to death? and more than so, my father,
Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years,
When nature brought him to the door of death?
No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm,
This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: And I the house of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside,
While I use further conference with Warwick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Now Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience,
Is Edward your true king? for I were loath
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: But is he gracious in the people's eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Then further, all dissembling set aside,
Tell me for truth the measure of his love
Unto our sister Bona.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Such it seems
As may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have often heard him say and swear
That this his love was an eternal plant,
Whereof the root was fix'd in virtue's ground,
The leaves and fruit maintain'd with beauty's sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,
Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BONA
SPEECH.LINE: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine:
Yet I confess that often ere this day,
When I have heard your king's desert recounted,
Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's;
And now forthwith shall articles be drawn
Touching the jointure that your king must make,
Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.
Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness
That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: To Edward, but not to the English king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device
By this alliance to make void my suit:
Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: And still is friend to him and Margaret:
But if your title to the crown be weak,
As may appear by Edward's good success,
Then 'tis but reason that I be released
From giving aid which late I promised.
Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
That your estate requires and mine can yield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease,
Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.
And as for you yourself, our quondam queen,
You have a father able to maintain you;
And better 'twere you troubled him than France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace,
Proud setter up and puller down of kings!
I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears,
Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold
Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love;
For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: To WARWICK My lord ambassador, these letters are for you,
Sent from your brother, Marquess Montague:
These from our king unto your majesty:
And, madam, these for you; from whom I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: I like it well that our fair queen and mistress
Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps, as he were nettled:
I hope all's for the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: What! has your king married the Lady Grey!
And now, to soothe your forgery and his,
Sends me a paper to persuade me patience?
Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?
Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: I told your majesty as much before:
This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: King Lewis, I here protest, in sight of heaven,
And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss,
That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward's,
No more my king, for he dishonours me,
But most himself, if he could see his shame.
Did I forget that by the house of York
My father came untimely to his death?
Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?
Did I impale him with the regal crown?
Did I put Henry from his native right?
And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame?
Shame on himself! for my desert is honour:
And to repair my honour lost for him,
I here renounce him and return to Henry.
My noble queen, let former grudges pass,
And henceforth I am thy true servitor:
I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his former state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love;
And I forgive and quite forget old faults,
And joy that thou becomest King Henry's friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend,
That, if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us
With some few bands of chosen soldiers,
I'll undertake to land them on our coast
And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
'Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him:
And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me,
He's very likely now to fall from him,
For matching more for wanton lust than honour,
Or than for strength and safety of our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BONA
SPEECH.LINE: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged
But by thy help to this distressed queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live,
Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BONA
SPEECH.LINE: My quarrel and this English queen's are one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's.
Therefore at last I firmly am resolved
You shall have aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Then, England's messenger, return in post,
And tell false Edward, thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride:
Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BONA
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly,
I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside,
And I am ready to put armour on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.
There's thy reward: be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: But, Warwick,
Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,
Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle;
And, as occasion serves, this noble queen
And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt,
What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: This shall assure my constant loyalty,
That if our queen and this young prince agree,
I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy
To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.
Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous,
Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick;
And, with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable,
That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it;
And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He gives his hand to WARWICK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING LEWIS XI
SPEECH.LINE: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied,
And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral,
Shalt waft them over with our royal fleet.
I long till Edward fall by war's mischance,
For mocking marriage with a dame of France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: I came from Edward as ambassador,
But I return his sworn and mortal foe:
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,
But dreadful war shall answer his demand.
Had he none else to make a stale but me?
Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.
I was the chief that raised him to the crown,
And I'll be chief to bring him down again:
Not that I pity Henry's misery,
But seek revenge on Edward's mockery.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. London. The palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, SOMERSET, and MONTAGUE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you
Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?
Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, you know, 'tis far from hence to France;
How could he stay till Warwick made return?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And his well-chosen bride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, attended; QUEEN ELIZABETH, PEMBROKE, STAFFORD, HASTINGS, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice,
That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick,
Which are so weak of courage and in judgment
That they'll take no offence at our abuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Suppose they take offence without a cause,
They are but Lewis and Warwick: I am Edward,
Your king and Warwick's, and must have my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And shall have your will, because our king:
Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Not I:
No, God forbid that I should wish them sever'd
Whom God hath join'd together; ay, and 'twere pity
To sunder them that yoke so well together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside,
Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey
Should not become my wife and England's queen.
And you too, Somerset and Montague,
Speak freely what you think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis
Becomes your enemy, for mocking him
About the marriage of the Lady Bona.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge,
Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased
By such invention as I can devise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Yet, to have join'd with France in such alliance
Would more have strengthen'd this our commonwealth
'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, knows not Montague that of itself
England is safe, if true within itself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis better using France than trusting France:
Let us be back'd with God and with the seas
Which He hath given for fence impregnable,
And with their helps only defend ourselves;
In them and in ourselves our safety lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, what of that? it was my will and grant;
And for this once my will shall stand for law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And yet methinks your grace hath not done well,
To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales
Unto the brother of your loving bride;
She better would have fitted me or Clarence:
But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir
Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son,
And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, poor Clarence! is it for a wife
That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: In choosing for yourself, you show'd your judgment,
Which being shallow, you give me leave
To play the broker in mine own behalf;
And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king,
And not be tied unto his brother's will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: My lords, before it pleased his majesty
To raise my state to title of a queen,
Do me but right, and you must all confess
That I was not ignoble of descent;
And meaner than myself have had like fortune.
But as this title honours me and mine,
So your dislike, to whom I would be pleasing,
Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns:
What danger or what sorrow can befall thee,
So long as Edward is thy constant friend,
And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?
Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too,
Unless they seek for hatred at my hands;
Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe,
And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside I hear, yet say not much, but think the more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now, messenger, what letters or what news
From France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words,
But such as I, without your special pardon,
Dare not relate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief,
Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them.
What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: At my depart, these were his very words:
'Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry.
But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: These were her words, utter'd with mad disdain:
'Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly,
I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: I blame not her, she could say little less;
She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen?
For I have heard that she was there in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tell him,' quoth she, 'my mourning weeds are done,
And I am ready to put armour on.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Belike she minds to play the Amazon.
But what said Warwick to these injuries?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: He, more incensed against your majesty
Than all the rest, discharged me with these words:
'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?
Well I will arm me, being thus forewarn'd:
They shall have wars and pay for their presumption.
But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so link'd in
friendship
That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.
Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast,
For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter;
That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage
I may not prove inferior to yourself.
You that love me and Warwick, follow me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Not I:
My thoughts aim at a further matter; I
Stay not for the love of Edward, but the crown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick!
Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen;
And haste is needful in this desperate case.
Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf
Go levy men, and make prepare for war;
They are already, or quickly will be landed:
Myself in person will straight follow you.
But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague,
Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest,
Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance:
Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?
If it be so, then both depart to him;
I rather wish you foes than hollow friends:
But if you mind to hold your true obedience,
Give me assurance with some friendly vow,
That I may never have you in suspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: So God help Montague as he proves true!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why, so! then am I sure of victory.
Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour,
Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. A plain in Warwickshire.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter WARWICK and OXFORD, with French soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well;
The common people by numbers swarm to us.
But see where Somerset and Clarence come!
Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Fear not that, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick;
And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice
To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love;
Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother,
Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings:
But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine.
And now what rests but, in night's coverture,
Thy brother being carelessly encamp'd,
His soldiers lurking in the towns about,
And but attended by a simple guard,
We may surprise and take him at our pleasure?
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy:
That as Ulysses and stout Diomede
With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus' tents,
And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds,
So we, well cover'd with the night's black mantle,
At unawares may beat down Edward's guard
And seize himself; I say not, slaughter him,
For I intend but only to surprise him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.
Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort:
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Edward's camp, near Warwick.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter three Watchmen, to guard KING EDWARD IV's tent

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand:
The king by this is set him down to sleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: What, will he not to bed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow
Never to lie and take his natural rest
Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: To-morrow then belike shall be the day,
If Warwick be so near as men report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that
That with the king here resteth in his tent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: O, is it so? But why commands the king
That his chief followers lodge in towns about him,
While he himself keeps in the cold field?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but give me worship and quietness;
I like it better than a dangerous honour.
If Warwick knew in what estate he stands,
'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent,
But to defend his person from night-foes?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter WARWICK, CLARENCE, OXFORD, SOMERSET, and French soldiers, silent all

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard.
Courage, my masters! honour now or never!
But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Who goes there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Watchman
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, or thou diest!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: WARWICK and the rest cry all, 'Warwick! Warwick!' and set upon the Guard, who fly, crying, 'Arm! arm!' WARWICK and the rest following them
The drum playing and trumpet sounding, reenter WARWICK, SOMERSET, and the rest, bringing KING EDWARD IV out in his gown, sitting in a chair. RICHARD and HASTINGS fly over the stage

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: What are they that fly there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted,
Thou call'dst me king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but the case is alter'd:
When you disgraced me in my embassade,
Then I degraded you from being king,
And come now to create you Duke of York.
Alas! how should you govern any kingdom,
That know not how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to be contented with one wife,
Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,
Nor how to study for the people's welfare,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too?
Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.
Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance,
Of thee thyself and all thy complices,
Edward will always bear himself as king:
Though fortune's malice overthrow my state,
My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king:
But Henry now shall wear the English crown,
And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd
Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.
When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows,
I'll follow you, and tell what answer
Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him.
Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: What fates impose, that men must needs abide;
It boots not to resist both wind and tide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: What now remains, my lords, for us to do
But march to London with our soldiers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do;
To free King Henry from imprisonment
And see him seated in the regal throne.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. London. The palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn
What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: What! loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: Then is my sovereign slain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner,
Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard
Or by his foe surprised at unawares:
And, as I further have to understand,
Is new committed to the Bishop of York,
Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: These news I must confess are full of grief;
Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:
Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.
And I the rather wean me from despair
For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
This is it that makes me bridle passion
And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;
Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear
And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs,
Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown
King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: I am inform'd that he comes towards London,
To set the crown once more on Henry's head:
Guess thou the rest; King Edward's friends must down,
But, to prevent the tyrant's violence,--
For trust not him that hath once broken faith,--
I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary,
To save at least the heir of Edward's right:
There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.
Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly:
If Warwick take us we are sure to die.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. A park near Middleham Castle In Yorkshire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley,
Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither,
Into this chiefest thicket of the park.
Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother,
Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands
He hath good usage and great liberty,
And, often but attended with weak guard,
Comes hunting this way to disport himself.
I have advertised him by secret means
That if about this hour he make his way
Under the colour of his usual game,
He shall here find his friends with horse and men
To set him free from his captivity.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter KING EDWARD IV and a Huntsman with him

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Huntsman
SPEECH.LINE: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand.
Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Stand you thus close, to steal the bishop's deer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, the time and case requireth haste:
Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But whither shall we then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: To Lynn, my lord,
And ship from thence to Flanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Well guess'd, believe me; for that was my meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Huntsman, what say'st thou? wilt thou go along?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Huntsman
SPEECH.LINE: Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwick's frown;
And pray that I may repossess the crown.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. London. The Tower.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, CLARENCE, WARWICK, SOMERSET, HENRY OF RICHMOND, OXFORD, MONTAGUE, and Lieutenant of the Tower

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Master lieutenant, now that God and friends
Have shaken Edward from the regal seat,
And turn'd my captive state to liberty,
My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys,
At our enlargement what are thy due fees?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieutenant
SPEECH.LINE: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns;
But if an humble prayer may prevail,
I then crave pardon of your majesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: For what, lieutenant? for well using me?
Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness,
For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;
Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds
Conceive when after many moody thoughts
At last by notes of household harmony
They quite forget their loss of liberty.
But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me free,
And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee;
He was the author, thou the instrument.
Therefore, that I may conquer fortune's spite
By living low, where fortune cannot hurt me,
And that the people of this blessed land
May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars,
Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,
I here resign my government to thee,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous;
And now may seem as wise as virtuous,
By spying and avoiding fortune's malice,
For few men rightly temper with the stars:
Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace,
For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway,
To whom the heavens in thy nativity
Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown,
As likely to be blest in peace and war;
And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: And I choose Clarence only for protector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands:
Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,
That no dissension hinder government:
I make you both protectors of this land,
While I myself will lead a private life
And in devotion spend my latter days,
To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: That he consents, if Warwick yield consent;
For on thy fortune I repose myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content:
We'll yoke together, like a double shadow
To Henry's body, and supply his place;
I mean, in bearing weight of government,
While he enjoys the honour and his ease.
And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful
Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor,
And all his lands and goods be confiscate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: What else? and that succession be determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: But, with the first of all your chief affairs,
Let me entreat, for I command no more,
That Margaret your queen and my son Edward
Be sent for, to return from France with speed;
For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear
My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that,
Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, England's hope.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Lays his hand on his head
SPEECH.LINE: If secret powers
Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts,
This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss.
His looks are full of peaceful majesty,
His head by nature framed to wear a crown,
His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself
Likely in time to bless a regal throne.
Make much of him, my lords, for this is he
Must help you more than you are hurt by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: What news, my friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: That Edward is escaped from your brother,
And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Unsavoury news! but how made he escape?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Post
SPEECH.LINE: He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester
And the Lord Hastings, who attended him
In secret ambush on the forest side
And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him;
For hunting was his daily exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: My brother was too careless of his charge.
But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide
A salve for any sore that may betide.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but SOMERSET, HENRY OF RICHMOND, and OXFORD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's;
For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help,
And we shall have more wars before 't be long.
As Henry's late presaging prophecy
Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond,
So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts
What may befall him, to his harm and ours:
Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst,
Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany,
Till storms be past of civil enmity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown,
'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: It shall be so; he shall to Brittany.
Come, therefore, let's about it speedily.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VII. Before York.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and Soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends,
And says that once more I shall interchange
My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas
And brought desired help from Burgundy:
What then remains, we being thus arrived
From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York,
But that we enter, as into our dukedom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this;
For many men that stumble at the threshold
Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us:
By fair or foul means we must enter in,
For hither will our friends repair to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, on the walls, the Mayor of York, and his Brethren

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming,
And shut the gates for safety of ourselves;
For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But, master mayor, if Henry be your king,
Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom,
As being well content with that alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside But when the fox hath once got in his nose,
He'll soon find means to make the body follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt?
Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be open'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: The good old man would fain that all were well,
So 'twere not 'long of him; but being enter'd,
I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade
Both him and all his brothers unto reason.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Mayor and two Aldermen, below

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut
But in the night or in the time of war.
What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys;
For Edward will defend the town and thee,
And all those friends that deign to follow me.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: March. Enter MONTGOMERY, with drum and soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery,
Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: To help King Edward in his time of storm,
As every loyal subject ought to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget
Our title to the crown and only claim
Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Then fare you well, for I will hence again:
I came to serve a king and not a duke.
Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhile, and we'll debate
By what safe means the crown may be recover'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: What talk you of debating? in few words,
If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king,
I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone
To keep them back that come to succor you:
Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim:
Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns.
Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand:
The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right,
And Henry but usurps the diadem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself;
And now will I be Edward's champion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd:
Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of
England and France, and lord of Ireland, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right,
By this I challenge him to single fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Long live Edward the Fourth!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all:
If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness.
Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York;
And when the morning sun shall raise his car
Above the border of this horizon,
We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates;
For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.
Ah, froward Clarence! how evil it beseems thee
To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother!
Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick.
Come on, brave soldiers: doubt not of the day,
And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VIII. London. The palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, WARWICK, MONTAGUE, CLARENCE, EXETER, and OXFORD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia,
With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders,
Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas,
And with his troops doth march amain to London;
And many giddy people flock to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Let's levy men, and beat him back again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: A little fire is quickly trodden out;
Which, being suffer'd, rivers cannot quench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war;
Those will I muster up: and thou, son Clarence,
Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk, and in Kent,
The knights and gentlemen to come with thee:
Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham,
Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find
Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:
And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved,
In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.
My sovereign, with the loving citizens,
Like to his island girt in with the ocean,
Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs,
Shall rest in London till we come to him.
Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply.
Farewell, my sovereign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: In sign of truth, I kiss your highness' hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague,
And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but KING HENRY VI and EXETER

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Here at the palace I will rest awhile.
Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship?
Methinks the power that Edward hath in field
Should not be able to encounter mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame:
I have not stopp'd mine ears to their demands,
Nor posted off their suits with slow delays;
My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds,
My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs,
My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;
I have not been desirous of their wealth,
Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies.
Nor forward of revenge, though they much err'd:
Then why should they love Edward more than me?
No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace:
And when the lion fawns upon the lamb,
The lamb will never cease to follow him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, hark, my lord! what shouts are these?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence;
And once again proclaim us King of England.
You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow:
Now stops thy spring; my sea sha$l suck them dry,
And swell so much the higher by their ebb.
Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Exeunt some with KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course
Where peremptory Warwick now remains:
The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay,
Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Away betimes, before his forces join,
And take the great-grown traitor unawares:
Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Coventry.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter WARWICK, the Mayor of Coventry, two Messengers, and others upon the walls

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?
How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: How far off is our brother Montague?
Where is the post that came from Montague?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son?
And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: At Southam I did leave him with his forces,
And do expect him here some two hours hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies:
The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Who should that be? belike, unlook'd-for friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: March: flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come?
Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced,
That we could hear no news of his repair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates,
Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee,
Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy?
And he shall pardon thee these outrages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence,
Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own,
Call Warwick patron and be penitent?
And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I thought, at least, he would have said the king;
Or did he make the jest against his will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give:
I'll do thee service for so good a gift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight:
And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again;
And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner:
And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this:
What is the body when the head is off?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast,
But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten,
The king was slily finger'd from the deck!
You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace,
And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down:
Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow,
And with the other fling it at thy face,
Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend,
This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair
Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off,
Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood,
'Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.'

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter OXFORD, with drum and colours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He and his forces enter the city

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The gates are open, let us enter too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: So other foes may set upon our backs.
Stand we in good array; for they no doubt
Will issue out again and bid us battle:
If not, the city being but of small defence,
We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter MONTAGUE with drum and colours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He and his forces enter the city

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason
Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: The harder match'd, the greater victory:
My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter SOMERSET, with drum and colours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He and his forces enter the city

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset,
Have sold their lives unto the house of York;
And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along,
Of force enough to bid his brother battle;
With whom an upright zeal to right prevails
More than the nature of a brother's love!
Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt, if Warwick call.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Father of Warwick, know you what this means?
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Taking his red rose out of his hat
SPEECH.LINE: Look here, I throw my infamy at thee
I will not ruinate my father's house,
Who gave his blood to lime the stones together,
And set up Lancaster. Why, trow'st thou, Warwick,
That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural,
To bend the fatal instruments of war
Against his brother and his lawful king?
Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:
To keep that oath were more impiety
Than Jephthah's, when he sacrificed his daughter.
I am so sorry for my trespass made
That, to deserve well at my brother's hands,
I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe,
With resolution, wheresoe'er I meet thee--
As I will meet thee, if thou stir abroad--
To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.
And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee,
And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.
Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends:
And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults,
For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved,
Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight?
Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence!
I will away towards Barnet presently,
And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way.
Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory!
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Exeunt King Edward and his company. March. Warwick and his company follow
SPEECH.LINE: 3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. A field of battle near Barnet.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum and excursions. Enter KING EDWARD IV, bringing forth WARWICK wounded

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear;
For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all.
Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee,
That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend or foe,
And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick?
Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,
My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.
That I must yield my body to the earth
And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.
Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge,
Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle,
Under whose shade the ramping lion slept,
Whose top-branch overpeer'd Jove's spreading tree
And kept low shrubs from winter's powerful wind.
These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's black veil,
Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun,
To search the secret treasons of the world:
The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood,
Were liken'd oft to kingly sepulchres;
For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?
And who durst mine when Warwick bent his brow?
Lo, now my glory smear'd in dust and blood!
My parks, my walks, my manors that I had.
Even now forsake me, and of all my lands
Is nothing left me but my body's length.
Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?
And, live we how we can, yet die we must.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are.
We might recover all our loss again;
The queen from France hath brought a puissant power:
Even now we heard the news: ah, could'st thou fly!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague,
If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand.
And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile!
Thou lovest me not; for, brother, if thou didst,
Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood
That glues my lips and will not let me speak.
Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breathed his last;
And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick,
And said 'Commend me to my valiant brother.'
And more he would have said, and more he spoke,
Which sounded like a clamour in a vault,
That mought not be distinguished; but at last
I well might hear, delivered with a groan,
'O, farewell, Warwick!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves;
For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away, to meet the queen's great power!
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Here they bear away his body. Exeunt
SPEECH.LINE: 3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Another part of the field.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV in triumph; with GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course,
And we are graced with wreaths of victory.
But, in the midst of this bright-shining day,
I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud,
That will encounter with our glorious sun,
Ere he attain his easeful western bed:
I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen
Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast
And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud
And blow it to the source from whence it came:
The very beams will dry those vapours up,
For every cloud engenders not a storm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The queen is valued thirty thousand strong,
And Somerset, with Oxford fled to her:
If she have time to breathe be well assured
Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: We are advertised by our loving friends
That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury:
We, having now the best at Barnet field,
Will thither straight, for willingness rids way;
And, as we march, our strength will be augmented
In every county as we go along.
Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Plains near Tewksbury.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: March. Enter QUEEN MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, SOMERSET, OXFORD, and soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss,
But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
What though the mast be now blown overboard,
The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost,
And half our sailors swallow'd in the flood?
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that he
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
With tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more strength to that which hath too much,
Whiles, in his moan, the ship splits on the rock,
Which industry and courage might have saved?
Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this!
Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?
And Montague our topmost; what of him?
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
Why, is not Oxford here another anchor?
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I
For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to sit and weep,
But keep our course, though the rough wind say no,
From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck.
As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.
And what is Edward but ruthless sea?
What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?
All these the enemies to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!
Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink:
Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off,
Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.
This speak I, lords, to let you understand,
If case some one of you would fly from us,
That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers
More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided
'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit
Should, if a coward heard her speak these words,
Infuse his breast with magnanimity
And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.
I speak not this as doubting any here
For did I but suspect a fearful man
He should have leave to go away betimes,
Lest in our need he might infect another
And make him of like spirit to himself.
If any such be here--as God forbid!--
Let him depart before we need his help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Women and children of so high a courage,
And warriors faint! why, 'twere perpetual shame.
O brave young prince! thy famous grandfather
Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live
To bear his image and renew his glories!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: And he that will not fight for such a hope.
Go home to bed, and like the owl by day,
If he arise, be mock'd and wonder'd at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand.
Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: I thought no less: it is his policy
To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: But he's deceived; we are in readiness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish and march. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood,
Which, by the heavens' assistance and your strength,
Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.
I need not add more fuel to your fire,
For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out
Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say
My tears gainsay; for every word I speak,
Ye see, I drink the water of mine eyes.
Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign,
Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd,
His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain,
His statutes cancell'd and his treasure spent;
And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.
You fight in justice: then, in God's name, lords,
Be valiant and give signal to the fight.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. Another part of the field.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers; with QUEEN MARGARET, OXFORD, and SOMERSET, prisoners

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Now here a period of tumultuous broils.
Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight:
For Somerset, off with his guilty head.
Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: OXFORD
SPEECH.LINE: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: So part we sadly in this troublous world,
To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Is proclamation made, that who finds Edward
Shall have a high reward, and he his life?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: It is: and lo, where youthful Edward comes!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak.
What! can so young a thorn begin to prick?
Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make
For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects,
And all the trouble thou hast turn'd me to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York!
Suppose that I am now my father's mouth;
Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,
Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee,
Which traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: That you might still have worn the petticoat,
And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Let AEsop fable in a winter's night;
His currish riddles sort not with this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Untutor'd lad, thou art too malapert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: I know my duty; you are all undutiful:
Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George,
And thou mis-shapen Dick, I tell ye all
I am your better, traitors as ye are:
And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Take that, thou likeness of this railer here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Sprawl'st thou? take that, to end thy agony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: And there's for twitting me with perjury.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: O, kill me too!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, and shall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Why should she live, to fill the world with words?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: What, doth she swoon? use means for her recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother;
I'll hence to London on a serious matter:
Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: What? what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The Tower, the Tower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: O Ned, sweet Ned! speak to thy mother, boy!
Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers!
They that stabb'd Caesar shed no blood at all,
Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame,
If this foul deed were by to equal it:
He was a man; this, in respect, a child:
And men ne'er spend their fury on a child.
What's worse than murderer, that I may name it?
No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak:
And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.
Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals!
How sweet a plant have you untimely cropp'd!
You have no children, butchers! if you had,
The thought of them would have stirr'd up remorse:
But if you ever chance to have a child,
Look in his youth to have him so cut off
As, deathmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here,
Here sheathe thy sword, I'll pardon thee my death:
What, wilt thou not? then, Clarence, do it thou.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself:
'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity.
What, wilt thou not? Where is that devil's butcher,
Hard-favour'd Richard? Richard, where art thou?
Thou art not here: murder is thy alms-deed;
Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: So come to you and yours, as to this Prince!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Richard gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CLARENCE
SPEECH.LINE: To London, all in post; and, as I guess,
To make a bloody supper in the Tower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING EDWARD IV
SPEECH.LINE: He's sudden, if a thing comes in his head.
Now march we hence: discharge the common sort
With pay and thanks, and let's away to London
And see our gentle queen how well she fares:
By this, I hope, she hath a son for me.
3 KING HENRY VI

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. London. The Tower.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter KING HENRY VI and GLOUCESTER, with the Lieutenant, on the walls

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Good day, my lord. What, at your book so hard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord:--my lord, I should say rather;
'Tis sin to flatter; 'good' was little better:
'Good Gloucester' and 'good devil' were alike,
And both preposterous; therefore, not 'good lord.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, leave us to ourselves: we must confer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf;
So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece
And next his throat unto the butcher's knife.
What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind;
The thief doth fear each bush an officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: The bird that hath been limed in a bush,
With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush;
And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird,
Have now the fatal object in my eye
Where my poor young was limed, was caught and kill'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
